I thought of AND/OR just because it's the behaviour of boolean AND/OR i=
f all 
the "PASS" decisions are ignored. However you call them, they have t=
he 
advantage that you do not have to evaluate all the rules in the chain. =
This 
should considerably speed up crawling.

Imagine the following setup:
=

DecideRuleSequence:
1. AcceptDecideRule
2. TooManyHopsDecideRule
3. TooMan=
yPathSegmentsDecideRule
4. PathologicalPathDecideRule
5. SurtPrefixedDecide=
Rule (REJECT bad surts)
6. PrerequisiteAcceptDecideRule

This basically is =
a setting for a breadth-first crawl, with a limited scope 
(max-hops).

Cur=
rently, even if rule #2 (maxHops) returns a REJECT, Heritrix will evaluate =

rules #3, #4 and #5, which is not necessary and may take a lot of time 
(e=
specially SurtPrefixedDecideRule). With a RejectIfAnyDecideRuleSequence 
(y=
our suggested name is ok), it would look like the following:

DecideRuleSeq=
uence:
1. AcceptDecideRule
2. RejectIfAnyDecideRuleSequence:
  a. TooManyHo=
psDecideRule
  b. TooManyPathSegmentsDecideRule
  c. PathologicalPathDecide=
Rule
  d. SurtPrefixedDecideRule (REJECT bad surts)
3. PrerequisiteAcceptDe=
cideRule

While these latter rules have the same meaning as the former ones=
, they look 
much clearer and more understandable to me, and are even faste=
r to evaluate 
in most cases (because rule 2a. filters out most of the URLs=
